moves.1. e4: My name is Tony, I'm black in this game.  I am no grand master, just a student.  This game was fun, and really helped me learn to look for opportunities to pin my opponents pieces.   I'll start my annotation at move 17.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. Nc3 Nd4: I examined this position for ten minuets before I moved.  My white bishop has a strong position, and I was salivating for the chance to put my queen down on the h1 or g2 squares.  But at this point my queen seem trapped behind the menacing white pawn line.  Every white square beyond the pawn line is protected, and I cant get around the pawn line on the 6th row because of the knight on d4.  But then I noticed that knight shared a diagonal with the king, and I saw my chance to pin it there and get my queen out.
moves.19. Bb2 Qc6 20. Kf2: forced, but the knight is still pinned and I don't feel rushed to move my queen.
moves.20... d6: Instead I try to open up the e file.
moves.21. Ke1: Now I have to move my queen
moves.21... Qg2 22. exd6 Bxd6: efile open, I take the pawn back
moves.23. Qc3: and white moves his queen on the strong diagonal threatening the g7 pawn and checkmate after the knight on d4 moves; but I'm feeling pretty strong, and i don't think he has time because of his kings weak position.
moves.23... Rac8 24. Nc6: but suddenly I'm down to one move-  I have lots of options, and I took a long time before deciding. The line I choose results in a queen swap, and a very favorable position for me.
Rook and king on same diagonal
moves.33... b4+ 34. axb4 Bxb4+ 35. Kc2 Bxe1 36: maybe white wants to trade bishops?
moves.37. f5 f6 38. Kb2 Bxc3+ 39. Kc2 a4 40. K: and a discovered checkmate- fun game
